content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Search for the one-way flight available from Calgary to New York on May 1st, 2026 with the lowest carbon dioxide emissions.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To start the search, I need to enter "Calgary" as the departure city. The departure field currently shows "Toronto" and needs to be updated.
Action: Type [13]; Calgary
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure city is now set to "Calgary." Next, I need to enter "New York" as the destination city in the "Where to?" field.
Action: Type [14]; New York
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination is now set to "New York." The next step is to select the departure date ("Departure" field) to input May 1st, 2026.
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current calendar is showing September and October, but I need to select May 1st, 2026. Therefore, I need to keep navigating forward using the "Next" button until reaching May 2026.
Action: Click [74]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.37
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am currently viewing October and November, but need to reach May 2026. I should keep navigating forward by clicking the "Next" button.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.39
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays November and December. I need to continue clicking "Next" until reaching May 2026.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.40
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows December and January 2026. I am still not at May 2026, so I need to continue to progress forward by clicking the "Next" button.
Action: Click [76]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.42
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is now displaying January and February 2026. Since I need to select May 1st, 2026, I must continue clicking the "Next" button to advance the calendar.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.44
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows February and March 2026. I still need to move forward to reach May 2026, so I should continue clicking the "Next" button.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.46
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar view now shows March and April 2026, but May is still not visible. I need to click the "Next" button again to reach May 2026.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.48
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays May 2026. I need to select May 1st ("1$585") to set the correct departure date, and then click "Done" to proceed.
Action: Click [43]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure date is set to May 1, 2026. The next step is to confirm this date and search for one-way flights by clicking the "Done" button.
Action: Click [79]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: All the fields are correctly filled: "Calgary" as departure, "New York" as destination, and the travel date is set. To search for available flights, I need to click the "Search" button.
Action: Click [18]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search results seem to have led back to the calendar page, with May 1 already selected. To continue and view the flight options (where carbon emissions can be evaluated), I need to confirm the selection by clicking the "Done" button.
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search process seems to have reset to the initial flights search page, possibly because the "Return" date is still set. To ensure the search is for a one-way flight (as required), I need to change the trip type from "Round trip" to "One way."
Action: Click [10]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The option to change the trip type is expanded. I need to select "One way" to search only for a one-way flight from Calgary to New York.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.88
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: "One way" is now selected. Departure is "Calgary" and destination is "New York." We now need to select the correct departure date (May 1st, 2026) before searching for flights.
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 1
Completion: 0.9

Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[2]: <button> "Travel";	[3]: <button> "Explore";	[4]: <button> "Flights";	[5]: <button> "Hotels";	[6]: <button> "Vacation rentals";	[7]: <button> "Change appearance";	[9]: "Sign in";	[11]: <button> "1", "1 passenger";	[12]: <button> "Close dialog";	[14]: <input> "Where from?";	[15]: <button> "Swap origin and destination.";	[16]: <input> "Where to?";	[17]: <button> "";	[18]: <button> "";	[19]: <button> "Search";	[20]: <button> "Explore deals";

content:
Thought: All details are entered (one way, Calgary to New York). Now, I need to specify the departure date (May 1, 2026) by interacting with the departure field (likely one of the buttons with no text next to the seats icon).
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.92
